explanation:
To decide whether any controlling expression in OS_SocketAccept_Impl is invariant you need the following definitions/behaviors:

- OS_impl_file_internal_record_t: The struct definition is required to know the types and qualifiers (e.g. const/volatile) of its members. A member declared const/constexpr could make an "if" condition invariant at compile time.

- selectable (field of OS_impl_file_internal_record_t): The if (sock_impl->selectable) controlling expression depends directly on this field; we must know its type and whether it can be a compile-time constant or has volatile/side-effect semantics.

- fd (field of OS_impl_file_internal_record_t): The expression (conn_impl->fd < 0) depends on fd; knowing its type and qualifiers confirms whether that comparison can be considered invariant.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: This macro/function determines how sock_impl and conn_impl are derived from tokens. Its expansion can introduce casts/constness or constant pointers that affect whether the fields referenced are invariant.

- OS_impl_filehandle_table: The object table symbol used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET can be a static const table (making results invariant) or mutable; its definition is needed to determine whether returned records/fields can change at runtime.

- OS_SelectSingle_Impl: The code assigns operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE then (optionally) calls OS_SelectSingle_Impl(&operation). If OS_SelectSingle_Impl can modify the operation value (or can never be called because of selectable), then the subsequent test ((operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE) == 0) may or may not be invariant. We need the prototype and semantic behavior of OS_SelectSingle_Impl (does it modify operation, under what conditions, and can it be inlined/optimized away).

- OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE: The bitmask/constant used to initialize and test 'operation' must be known to determine whether the bit-test can be constant.

- OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT, OS_ERROR: The tests if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) and subsequent assignments use these constants; their values and types are needed to reason about invariance of comparisons and whether any comparisons could be reduced to constant true/false.

- accept: The POSIX accept() call sets conn_impl->fd and updates addrlen; to ascertain whether (conn_impl->fd < 0) is necessarily true/false or depends on runtime behavior we need the prototype/semantics of accept (i.e. it returns -1 on error).

- OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS: Although not part of a controlling expression, this macro/function may expand to other calls or qualifiers that affect the mutability/qualifiers of the socket record or may use token-to-index macros (affecting constness). Its definition helps ensure no hidden invariant is introduced after accept.

Collecting these symbols lets the next analyzer determine whether each controlling expression in OS_SocketAccept_Impl can be proven invariant (and thus a MISRA violation) or must be treated as runtime-dependent.
